Award.AwardTitle: CCI Phase I: NSF Center for Genomically Encoded Materials (C-GEM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing synthetic routes to polymers consisting of a defined sequence of monomers is a current challenge in chemistry. Proteins are natural polymers, and are specific sequences of amino acids put together easily and efficiently by the living cell. The NSF Center for Genomically Encoded Materials (C-GEM) takes a bio-inspired approach making a sequence of synthetic polymers by re-engineering the cell's systems. In this case, the cell becomes a new translational machine that synthesizes new chemical polymers of specific sequence and length. NSF C-GEM establishes a new, transformative field of chemistry and fosters innovation at the chemistry-biology-materials frontier. The applications of the new materials with novel properties range from information storage to anti-counterfeiting and drug delivery, from environmental remediation to drug discovery. NSF C-GEM engages scientists and non-scientists in a variety of research and educational activities, including improved communication to the public. These education and participation programs integrate research with training to establish a diverse chemical workforce. NSF C-GEM presents a new online platform and data management system, GEM-Net, to promote data sharing within and outside the research team. NSF C-GEM is also developing an online video game that allows citizen scientists to participate in the research process and track results.

The NSF Center for Genomically Encoded Materials, NSF C-GEM, is focused on the challenge of preparing polymers whose monomers and dispersity are defined with protein-like control. Sequence-defined polymers possess extraordinary potential for information storage, anti-counterfeiting, drug delivery, environmental remediation, and even drug discovery, but strategies to prepare them are barely in their infancy. NSF C-GEM's approach synthesizes sequence-defined chemical polymers by repurposing the E. coli translational apparatus. The translation machinery, which normally promotes bond formation between alpha-amino acids, now promotes bond-forming reactions between monomers that are the building blocks for aramids, polyolefins, polyurethanes, and other polymers. The approach demands orthogonal enzymes that acylate orthogonal tRNAs with each monomer, efficiently and in vivo; orthogonal ribosomes that accept these tRNAs as substrates and elongate the products; genomically-recoded organisms with multiple open codons to enable mRNA-templated synthesis of sequence-defined polymers; and high-resolution structural data to deepen understanding and inform design. The project develops the multi-disciplinary tools and technologies that demonstrate the proof of concept of the approach and establish practical methodologies to this aim. NSF C-GEM fosters innovation at the chemistry-biology-materials frontier, and engages scientists and non-scientists in research and educational activities. A diverse set of education and participation programs integrates research with training, establishes a diverse chemical workforce, and improves communication with the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The molecules that drive modern society--whether saving our planet and communities, or our lives and loved ones individually--are improving, but only slowly, and with considerable cost and consequence. The central problem is that we cannot code molecules as we code software. C-GEM seeks to change this reality by establishing a new class of chemical matter that combines the encoded precision of bio-polymers with the imagination-inspired diversity of synthetic materials: sequence-defined chemical polymers. These polymers have precise sequence and length, unique chemical functionality, and unprecedented novel properties. 

In Phase I, C-GEM laid the foundation for using the ribosome as the catalyst to generate such sequence-defined chemical polymers. The ribosome, a cellular RNA machine, catalyzes the formation of polypeptides with exceptional yield and fidelity based on the sequence encoded in messenger RNA in a process called translation. We demonstrated that the extant ribosome from the bacterium known as E. coli can incorporate a diversity of aramid and polyketide-like monomers at the N-terminus of a translated polypeptide [1], and developed a system for initiating translation in cells with non-canonical amino acids [2]. This cellular technology enabled the simultaneous incorporation of three different non-canonical amino acids in a single protein [3]. By harnessing the power of cryo-electron microscopy, C-GEM revealed previously unrecognized details about the proteins and RNAs that comprise the extant ribosome from E. coli [4] as well as  previously reported engineered ribosomes that incorporate beta-amino acids in vivo [5]. C-GEM researchers also developed tools to facilitate genome engineering and improve ribosome evolution [6]. C-GEM scientists continue to lead research to further this "bottom-up" strategy for synthesizing novel sequence-defined chemical polymers.

C-GEM's contributions to science in general and chemistry in particular go far beyond simply research. During Phase I, C-GEM students and postdoctoral researchers developed a week-long "Decoding Biology to Code New Materials" course for high school students and participated in career and professional development opportunities, including mock interviews with C-GEM industrial affiliates and a Twitter Chat in collaboration with Biochemistry. C-GEM collaborated with the scientific discovery game Eterna to create a "Ribosome Pilot Challenge," in which citizen scientist players were challenged to create more stable ribosomes. Development of the GEM-NET infrastructure catalyzed collaboration within the team, enabled seamless communication, and intuitive data management [8, 9]. Through highlights, review articles, and book chapters, C-GEM contributed key perspectives through the publication of viewpoints [10], review articles [11-14], and book chapters [15].  

 

1. O. Ad, K. S. Hoffman, et al., Translation of Diverse Aramid- and 1,3-Dicarbonyl-peptides by Wild Type Ribosomes in Vitro. ACS Cent. Sci., 2019, 5 (7), 1289-1294.

2. J. M. Tharp, O. Ad, et al., Initiation of Protein Synthesis with Non-Canonical Amino Acids In Vivo. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed., 2020, 59 (8), 3122-3126.

3. J. M. Tharp, O. Vargas-Rodriguez, et al., Genetic Encoding of Three Distinct Noncanonical Amino Acids Using Reprogrammed Initiator and Nonsense Codons. ACS Chem. Biol., 2021, 16 (4), 766-774.

4. Z. L. Watson, F. R. Ward, et al., Structure of the bacterial ribosome at 2Aresolution. eLife, 2020, 9, e60482.

5. F. R. Ward, Z. L. Watson, et al., Defects in the Assembly of Ribosomes Selected for β-Amino Acid Incorporation. Biochemistry, 2019, 58 (45), 4494-4504.

6. A. S. Walker, W. P. Russ, et al., RNA sectors and allosteric function within the ribosome. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci., 2020, 117 (33), 19879-19887.

7. S. G. Gaffney, O. Ad, et al., GEM-NET: Lessons in Multi-Institution Teamwork Using Collaboration Software. ACS Cent. Sci., 2019, 5 (7), 1159-1169.

8. S. G. Gaffney, S. Smaga, et al., Chemsearch: collaborative compound libraries with structure-aware browsing. Bioinforma. Adv., 2021, 1 (1), vbab008. 

9. A. Schepartz, Foldamers wave to the ribosome. Nat. Chem., 2018, 10 (4), 377-379.

10. P. Arranz-Gibert, K. Vanderschuren, et al., Next-generation genetic code expansion. Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol., 2018, 46, 203-211.

11. O. Vargas-Rodriguez, A. Sevostyanova, et al., Upgrading aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases for genetic code expansion. Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol., 2018, 46, 115-122.

12. K. S. Hoffman, A. Crnković, et al., Versatility of Synthetic tRNAs in Genetic Code Expansion. Genes, 2018, 9 (11), 537.

13. J. M. Tharp, N. Krahn, et al., Hijacking Translation Initiation for Synthetic Biology. ChemBioChem, 2020, 21 (10), 1387-1396.

14. N. Krahn, J. M. Tharp, et al., "Engineering aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases for use in synthetic biology" in The Enzymes, (Academic Press, 2020).
